title: The Fall of an Empire or the Rise of Europe?
description: In the traditional historiographical narrative, the arrival of the “barbarians” corresponds to the end of the greatest civilization of the antique Mediterranean: the Roman Empire. But was the situation so simple? Who were these “barbarians”? And did the Empire really collapse or was it rather transformed? The goal of this course is to focus on the artistic, visual, material, and performative cultures that coexisted in this extraordinary moment of history. To reach this objective, we will firstly focus on the prejudices constructed from the Renaissance to our days about what was commonly considered as the “Dark Ages”. Secondly, we will be investigating the role of medias in the transformations of visual history: from sculptures to “bidimensional” images, from roll to codex, from the illusive image to the iconic one. Third, we will analyze the role played by the meeting of cultures – constitutive for the investigated period – in the birth of the “Middle Ages”.\n\nThis course is taught by the Department of Art History at Masaryk University.
prerequisites: None

title: Electrochemical Sensors in pharmaceutical and biomedical analysis (Electrosensors)
description:
In this teaching, we wish to introduce to the students the main electrodes (specific electrodes, oxygen sensor, glucose biosensor…) and the principles of the electrochemical methods used in the field of pharmaceutical and biomedical analysis. We consider to focus on the enzyme electrochemical biosensors, notably the glucose biosensor, and on the ion selective electrodes, e.g. calcium. These electrodes are used in the blood glucose and in the blood gas detections.
To get deeper insights into the basic processes of several biosensors, thermodynamics and kinetics of weak molecular interactions will be discussed in detail. Examples of host-guest interactions of bioactive guest molecules with cavity-shaped hosts (cyclodextrins, calixarenes, cavitands, cucurbiturils) and their immobilization onto the glassy carbon or platinum electrode surfaces by electro-polymerization will be presented.
This course, offered at 3 European universities, brings together European students from different universities. This unique approach allows students to benefit from a truly international and intercultural learning experience.

title: Citizenship of the European Union
description:
The aim of this course will be to provide students - who will often be European citizens - with knowledge of what European citizenship entails. The different dimensions of European citizenship will be addressed, including its history, its link with nationality and the rights it confers on EU citizens at the economic, social and political levels. Through the prism of European citizenship, the course will address many aspects of European Union law, from the role of the institutions to the substantive rules of various EU policies.

title: Eukaryotic Genetics - Discovering Genetics: a powerful toolkit to unravel the basis of life
description:
The aims of this course are to: 
> understand the transmission mode of one or more loci in eukaryotes 
> address genetic mapping processes through the study of polymorphic genetic markers 
> combine genetic mapping and morbid gene research 
> integrate statistical analysis into genetic analyses 
> discuss the creation of mutants in different model organisms and their use in genetics. 

At the end of this course, students should:
> know the basic notions of genetic transmission 
> master the concepts of genetic markers and their use in genetic mapping 
> understand and master some statistical approaches used in genetics 
> understand the major approaches of current genetic engineering 

The course will open on 9th February 2022  and end on 3rd May 2022.
It is divided into 12 sequences of 2h to 2h30 each, leading to a total of around 25h. This partially includes personnal work.
Each sequence is made of self-taken lectures, documents and works + 1h long optionnal tutorships (to correct works with you and allow you to ask questions).
A forum will reinforce the follow-up aspect, letting you ask your questions at any time. Questions will be answered in the tutorships, and written records will be put at your disposal.
Three evaluations ponctuate the course.

title: “Grimms Märchen im europäischen Kontext” (Grimms’ Fairy Tales in their European context)
description:
Section 1: Learning objectives

In this seminar, Grimms’ Fairy Tales are examined in their European context. We study multilingual sources of the historical collection from 1812/1815 and examine the specific adaptation and redaction of these sources for different reading publics. In this research process, we will profit from the linguistic diversity of the participants of the course (in the ideal case: with a collective of students that are German, Italian, French, Czech or Hungarian native speakers). The main course language will be German, however (so it aims primarily at students in the German departments of the partnership Universities). Apart from this historical-critical approach, we will observe modern transformations of Grimms’ Fairy Tales in different media (literature, performative arts and film), including the most recent adaptations in contemporary popculture such as Terry Gilliams fantasy movie “Brothers Grimm” (2005).

At the end of the seminar, participants will:
- have profound knowledge on Grimms' collection of fairy tales
- be able to critically examine and compare historical sources
- develop the competency to observe and describe the transformation of literary motives
- discover the adaption of fairy tales in different media


Section 2: Details of the learning scenario

The course will be taught in a digital format, including both synchronous (weekly zoom-meetings) and asynchronous (moodle-based source collection, videos and task assignments) modes of teaching. It will be held in co-teaching (both Vinzenz Hoppe and Kaspar Renner present in all sessions plus additional guest lecturers and experts).

Please consider a work-load per week of: 6 hours
The minimum technical requirements you need to participate are: e.g.: Internet for Zoom

title: German A1 online
description:
The course is aimed at learners with no or almost no prior knowledge of German. As a fully Moodle-based online learning material, it could serve as a self-directed learning activities within and beyond classroom courses. Built on an action-orientated approach, it addresses reception, production, interaction and mediation in terms of language activities in connection to language strategies in various, but typical areas of communication related to academic life. Therefore it does neither claim to “cover” the whole level A1 according to the CEFR nor to provide A1 exam training but instead to empower successful participants to take their first steps in a German speaking surrounding and – equally important – to manage their further language acquisition.

Upon successfully engaging in this course, learners:

-can recognise concrete information (e.g. places and times) on familiar topics encountered in everyday life, provided it is delivered slowly and clearly.
-can understand some expressions when people are discussing them: personal and academic life, hobbies or surroundings, provided the delivery is slow and clear.
-can understand instructions addressed carefully and slowly to them and follow short, simple directions.
-can understand very short, simple texts a single phrase at a time, picking up familiar names, words and basic phrases.
-can guess the probable meaning of an unknown word/sign that is similar to one in the language they normally use.
-can produce simple, mainly isolated phrases about people, time and places. 
-can ask and answer simple questions, initiate and respond to simple statements in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics.
-can make an introduction and use basic greeting and leave-taking expressions. 
-can ask for food and drink using basic expressions.
-can handle numbers, quantities, cost and time.

The course design will be topic-related (myself getting to know others, food and shopping, time and appointments, places and local orientation, academic life) with a modular yet interlinked structure. Each module will be organised along five steps (expose oneself & recognise, explain & understand, practise, apply & act, reflect & test) and be focusing on reception, production, interaction and mediation activities and the respective strategies.
